news_summary: Recent discoveries of 12,000-year-old rock art in Arabia shed light on a lost ancient civilization, enriching our understanding of human history.
news_summary_fr: De récentes découvertes d'art rupestre datant de 12 000 ans en Arabie mettent en lumière une ancienne civilisation disparue, enrichissant ainsi notre compréhension de l'histoire de l'humanité.
news_summary_es: Recientes descubrimientos de arte rupestre de 12.000 años de antigüedad en Arabia arrojan luz sobre una antigua civilización perdida, enriqueciendo nuestra comprensión de la historia humana.

articles.title: 12,000-year-old rock art found in Arabia reveals a lost civilization
articles.summary: Archaeologists in Saudi Arabia discovered over 170 ancient rock engravings that may be among the earliest monumental artworks in the region. Created between 12,800 and 11,400 years ago, the massive figures were carved when water and life returned to the desert. The art likely marked territories and migration routes, revealing social and symbolic sophistication. Artifacts found nearby show early Arabian peoples connected to distant Neolithic communities.
articles.content:
Recent research has revealed the crucial role of early human groups who settled in northern Arabia soon after the intensely dry period known as the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM). These communities followed the return of seasonal water sources and left behind an extraordinary record of their presence through monumental rock art.

An international team of archaeologists, coordinated by the Heritage Commission of the Saudi Ministry of Culture, uncovered the findings through the Green Arabia Project. The team included experts from the Max Planck Institute of Geoanthropology, KAUST (King Abdullah University of Science and Technology), University College London, Griffith University, and several other institutions.

Researchers documented over 60 rock art panels featuring 176 individual engravings across three previously unexplored locations: Jebel Arnaan, Jebel Mleiha, and Jebel Misma, situated along the southern edge of the Nefud Desert in northern Saudi Arabia.

The engravings, which depict animals such as camels, ibex, equids, gazelles, and aurochs, include 130 highly detailed and life-sized figures, some reaching up to 3 meters long and more than 2 meters tall.

Dating to between 12,800 and 11,400 years ago, the engravings correspond to a time when temporary lakes and rivers reappeared after centuries of extreme aridity.

Sediment analysis confirmed the existence of these ancient water sources, which would have provided essential support for human groups venturing into the desert interior and allowed them to survive in this challenging environment.

"These large engravings are not just rock art -- they were probably statements of presence, access, and cultural identity," said lead author, Dr. Maria Guagnin from Max Planck Institute of Geoanthropology.

Dr. Ceri Shipton, co-lead author from the Institute of Archaeology, University College London, said: "The rock art marks water sources and movement routes, possibly signifying territorial rights and intergenerational memory."

Unlike previously known sites where engravings were hidden in crevices, the Jebel Mleiha and the Jebel Arnaan panels were etched onto towering cliff faces, some up to 39 meters high, in visually commanding locations.

One panel would have required ancient artists to climb and work precariously on narrow ledges, underscoring the sheer effort and significance of the imagery.

Artefacts including Levantine-style El Khiam and Helwan stone points, green pigment, and dentalium beads suggest long-distance connections to Pre-Pottery Neolithic (PPN) populations in the Levant region.

However, the scale, content, and placement of the Arabian engravings set them apart.

"This unique form of symbolic expression belongs to a distinct cultural identity adapted to life in a challenging, arid environment," said Dr. Faisal Al-Jibreen, from the Heritage Commmission, Saudi Ministry of Culture.

"The project's interdisciplinary approach has begun to fill a critical gap in the archaeological record of northern Arabia between the LGM and the Holocene, shedding light on the resilience and innovation of early desert communities," said Michael Petraglia, lead of the Green Arabia project.

The study 'Monumental rock art illustrates that humans thrived in the Arabian Desert during the Pleistocene-Holocene transition' has been published in Nature Communications.
articles.reasoning: The discovery of 12,000-year-old monumental rock art in northern Arabia reveals significant insights into early human civilization, cultural identity, and adaptation to harsh environments. The findings have broad archaeological and anthropological significance, shedding light on human resilience and social complexity during a critical climatic transition. The research involves an international collaboration and fills a major gap in understanding prehistoric human history in a large region, offering meaningful benefits to global knowledge and heritage preservation.
articles.personality_title: Ancient rock art in Saudi Arabia reveals early desert civilization
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Around 12,000 years ago, northern Arabia was once a dry desert but then experienced a return of water in the form of temporary lakes and rivers. Early human groups moved into this area after a long dry period called the Last Glacial Maximum.

**What happened** – Archaeologists discovered more than 170 large rock engravings at three sites in northern Saudi Arabia: Jebel Arnaan, Jebel Mleiha, and Jebel Misma. These pictures, carved between 12,800 and 11,400 years ago, show animals like camels, ibex, and gazelles. Some figures are life-sized, reaching up to 3 meters long. The art was found on tall cliffs, showing people put great effort into making them.

**Impact** – This discovery shows that early Arabian people had complex social lives and used art to mark territories and migration routes. The location and size of the engravings suggest they were important cultural symbols. Nearby artifacts also connect these groups to distant communities in the Levant, highlighting early long-distance links. This helps fill a big gap in our knowledge of how humans lived in harsh desert environments during a key time of climate change.

**What's next step** – Researchers will continue studying these sites to learn more about the people who made the art and how they survived. They also plan to use this information to protect the sites and share their importance with the public, helping preserve this ancient heritage.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Ancient rock art in northern Saudi Arabia reveals that early humans created large, meaningful artworks to show their presence and adapt to life in a changing desert environment.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des gravures rupestres anciennes en Arabie révèlent une civilisation désertique précoce
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Il y a environ 12 000 ans, le nord de l'Arabie était un désert sec avant que l'eau ne revienne sous forme de lacs et rivières temporaires. Des groupes humains s'y sont installés après une longue période sèche appelée le Dernier Maximum Glaciaire.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des archéologues ont découvert plus de 170 gravures rupestres monumentales sur trois sites en Arabie saoudite : Jebel Arnaan, Jebel Mleiha et Jebel Misma. Ces images, gravées entre 12 800 et 11 400 ans avant notre ère, montrent des animaux comme des chameaux, des bouquetins et des gazelles. Certaines figures font la taille réelle, atteignant jusqu'à 3 mètres de long. L'art se trouve sur de hautes falaises, prouvant l'effort important des artistes.

**Impact** – Cette découverte montre que les premiers habitants d'Arabie avaient une vie sociale complexe et utilisaient l'art pour marquer leurs territoires et routes migratoires. L'emplacement et la taille des gravures indiquent qu'elles étaient des symboles culturels importants. Des objets trouvés à proximité montrent aussi des liens avec des communautés lointaines du Levant, soulignant des connexions précoces à longue distance. Cela comble une grande lacune dans nos connaissances sur la vie humaine dans des environnements désertiques difficiles lors d'un changement climatique majeur.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs continueront d'étudier ces sites pour mieux comprendre les créateurs de ces gravures et leur mode de vie. Ils prévoient aussi de protéger ces lieux et de sensibiliser le public à leur importance pour préserver ce patrimoine ancien.

**Phrase clé** – Des gravures rupestres anciennes dans le nord de l'Arabie montrent que les premiers humains créaient de grands œuvres d'art pour marquer leur présence et s'adapter à la vie dans un désert en évolution.
articles.personality_title_es: Arte rupestre antiguo en Arabia Saudita revela una civilización temprana en el desierto
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Hace unos 12,000 años, el norte de Arabia era un desierto seco que luego recibió agua en forma de lagos y ríos temporales. Grupos humanos se establecieron allí después de un largo periodo seco llamado el Último Máximo Glacial.

**Qué pasó** – Arqueólogos descubrieron más de 170 grabados en roca grandes en tres sitios del norte de Arabia Saudita: Jebel Arnaan, Jebel Mleiha y Jebel Misma. Estas imágenes, talladas entre 12,800 y 11,400 años atrás, muestran animales como camellos, íbices y gacelas. Algunas figuras son del tamaño real, llegando hasta 3 metros de largo. El arte está en altos acantilados, mostrando que la gente puso mucho esfuerzo en crearlos.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo muestra que los primeros habitantes de Arabia tenían vidas sociales complejas y usaban el arte para marcar territorios y rutas migratorias. La ubicación y tamaño de los grabados indican que eran símbolos culturales importantes. Objetos encontrados cerca también conectan a estos grupos con comunidades lejanas en el Levante, destacando vínculos a larga distancia. Esto ayuda a llenar un gran vacío en nuestro conocimiento sobre cómo vivían los humanos en ambientes desérticos difíciles durante un cambio climático clave.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores seguirán estudiando estos sitios para aprender más sobre las personas que hicieron el arte y cómo sobrevivieron. También planean proteger los sitios y mostrar su importancia al público para preservar este patrimonio antiguo.

**Frase clave** – El arte rupestre antiguo en el norte de Arabia Saudita muestra que los primeros humanos crearon grandes obras con significado para mostrar su presencia y adaptarse a la vida en un desierto cambiante.
articles.image_prompt: A warm-toned detailed painting of towering desert cliffs etched with large, life-sized engravings of camels, ibex, and gazelles, with symbolic outlines of ancient water sources like flowing rivers and lakes below, set against a vast, arid Arabian landscape at sunset, capturing a sense of ancient human presence and cultural identity thriving in a challenging environment.
